responsePlaybook.essence: Meet their intensity without being pulled into it. Stay steady, recognise their drive, and channel it toward the collective good.
behaviors: I do not get personally affected by others' political agenda.
I give opportunities for growth to everyone on my team in accordance with the broader goals of the team/organization.
I remain calm and resilient in all situations.
I constructively challenge team members to put the collective good ahead of their personal interests.
I understand the politics played by others and can work through the system while keeping the organization's and employees' best interests in mind.
coachNotes: Name the boldness you see before proposing the balanced next step.
Use clarity of process ("Let's surface it together tomorrow") to slow the pace without diluting ambition.

responsePlaybook.essence: Honour what they are protecting while opening a doorway to explore new possibilities.
behaviors: I listen actively to my team members.
I do not dismiss my team member's concerns or judge them.
I create a safe space for myself and team members to be fully authentic.
I provide mentoring/coaching support to help team members overcome challenges.
I bolster stronger self-esteem in my team members.
I enable my team members to seek external help if they need so.
coachNotes: Slow your pace, mirror their desire for order, then invite experimentation with low-risk pilots.
Offer assurance that routines will not vanish; you are expanding capacity, not removing safeguards.

responsePlaybook.essence: Transform urgency into invitation. When someone is driven yet facing resistance, lead with respect, empathy and co-design.
behaviors: I motivate my team members to challenge status quo and have a voice of their own.
I encourage my team members to create the future in addition to managing the present.
I create a safe environment where team members can experiment and learn from failures.
I delegate with trust and therefore I do not micromanage.
I welcome new ideas and ways of working.
I provide them with a variety of interesting and challenging projects.
coachNotes: Pair your fire with warmth—"What would make this easier for you?" opens collaboration faster than directives.
Anchor conversations in shared purpose and trust before nudging for higher standards.

responsePlaybook.valueFamilyLabel: Aatma-Siddhi · Compassion / Oneness / Detachment / Greater Good
responsePlaybook.essence: Spot the quiet, purpose-led strength and invite it to influence without overpowering it.
behaviors: I create a culture of work done with fun and enjoyment.
I encourage team members to build capability both in areas of their interest and those that will challenge them.
I challenge them to also see the value in mundane work needed for the business.
I name the integrity, sincerity or depth I notice in them.
I invite them to represent the work when their voice can anchor a principled stand.
I celebrate their contribution without forcing visibility for its own sake.
coachNotes: Affirm their purpose orientation explicitly—"Your voice carries integrity".
Frame stretch opportunities as service to the mission, not personal spotlight.

caseStudy.title: Base Case · Leading Public Service Teams Through Values

scenes.title: Conflict Management
scenes.setting: District Planning Office · Aarav (Executive Engineer) & Ms. Iqbal (Senior Town Planner)
narrative: Aarav rushes in with a bold housing layout plan and wants to bypass committee layers to gain three months.
Ms. Iqbal receives the plan with composed attention, neither resisting nor yielding immediately.
Her equanimity slows Aarav's urgency; together they agree to surface the idea in the review table with space for discussion.
By staying steady, she allows Aarav to find his own balance instead of escalating the conflict.
reflectionQuestions: Can you recall a moment where you didn't react—and your stillness shifted the energy in the room?
How can you embody steadiness when someone brings heat, urgency or pressure?
What does it take to not take sides in conflict while still offering direction?

scenes.title: Mentoring & Inspiring Others
scenes.setting: Rural District Education Office · Anita (IAS officer) & Mr. Bhattacharya (mentor)
narrative: Anita pushes for higher standards but meets resistance from principals; she feels drained by the pushback.
Her mentor brings warmth (tea, curiosity) and reminds her how she was previously welcomed.
With Maitri—loving-kindness—he shifts her urgency into invitation, prompting her to co-design with stakeholders.
Anita re-engages the principal with empathy, asking what would make the change easier.
reflectionQuestions: Think of a time when your own drive or passion was met with resistance. How did you respond?
What would it look like to lead that moment with Maitri—loving-kindness?

scenes.title: Giving and Receiving Feedback Constructively
scenes.setting: District Health Office · Ramesh (senior admin) & Ms. Anasuya (mentor)
narrative: Ramesh protects established reporting formats and initially dismisses Neha's improvement idea.
Ms. Anasuya notices Neha's disappointment and gently invites Ramesh to hear her out.
She honours his intent to protect stability while encouraging compassion for new voices.
Ramesh later revisits Neha's draft, offering a pilot as a safe way to evolve the process.
reflectionQuestions: When someone resists change, do you only see rigidity—or do you pause to understand what they might be trying to protect?
How might you offer feedback that honours someone's need for stability while still inviting them to explore new possibilities?

scenes.title: Influencing & Negotiation
scenes.setting: Ministry of Environment · Sonal (Joint Secretary) & Kiran (technical consultant)
narrative: Sonal spots the depth in Kiran's policy section and wants him to present it at the forum.
Kiran prefers staying in the background; he is guided by Aatma-Siddhi—purpose over visibility.
Sonal affirms his integrity and frames the presentation as service to the work, not personal spotlight.
Through Mudita she convinces him to step up without overpowering his humility.
reflectionQuestions: Do you recognise people on your team who bring quiet, purpose-driven strength?
Can you find joy in encouraging them—not for credit, but because they matter?
How can you influence without overpowering when working with sincere, value-driven colleagues?

practiceQuestions.prompt: How would you apply Upeksha with someone like Aarav when they want to bypass process for speed?
Write how you would reopen a tense conversation using Maitri so that urgency turns into invitation.
Describe a Karuna-based response that honours a teammate's need for stability while nudging experimentation.
Draft the words you would use to invite a purpose-driven teammate to represent the work using Mudita.

canonicalGuidance.coachSummary: Stay steady, acknowledge the courage in bold moves, and suggest a transparent forum that keeps velocity without burning bridges.
Lead with warmth and respect, ask what would make the change easier, and co-create rather than impose.
Name the value of order they guard, invite them to pilot a new idea, and reassure them that their expertise anchors the change.
Affirm their sincerity, frame visibility as service, and celebrate their contribution so they feel seen, not used.
